Award.AwardTitle: Facility Support: The AfricaArray Geophysical and Meteorological Network
Award.AbstractNarration:
Pennsylvania State University and its African partners operate and maintain the 53-station AfricaArray (AA) network for geophysical and meteorological observations. The AA fills a critical gap in the global seismic network and GPS networks. The AA seismic and GPS data are being used to improve assessments of seismic hazards and risks in seismically active regions of Africa. The AA's GPS and weather data fill in critical observation gaps in weather and climate observing systems for parts of Africa. The AA education and outreach activities bring opportunities for students at minority-serving institutions in the U.S. to participate in AA research and it provides training for undergraduate and graduate students, postdocs and technicians in Africa.

This project funds Pennsylvania State University's continuing operation of the 53-station AfricaArray (AA). Each station is equipped with a combination of seismic, GPS and weather sensors. The AA addresses fundamental questions about the nature and evolution of continental rifting, cratons, hotspot volcanism, plateau uplift, and basin formation. The AA GPS data are greatly improving the ability to capture crustal movement caused by groundwater or soil moisture changes. The AA project sponsors underrepresented U.S. students and African undergraduate and graduate students, postdocs and technicians to study in a wide range of disciplines that benefit from AA observations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major goal of this project was to continue the operation and maintenance of the AfricaArray observatory network using the the five-element plan that worked successfully in the past.  The five elements are: 1) Routine servicing: In-country station operators provide routine servicing of equipment and data downloading.  2) Technicians: One full-time technician and one part-time technician work closely with the in-country station operators to maintain equipment. 3) Operating Funds: A budget pieced together from several funding sources supports technician salaries and routine costs such as equipment repair, travel, shipping, and communications. 4) Data management: Data management and processing is supported by the Royal Museum for Central Africa, and data archiving and distribution is provided by IRIS and UNAVCO.  5) Oversight: A network steering committee, consisting of the PI and the other AA co-Directors, provides oversight of all network operations.  In addition to maintaining the network, other goals of the project included training of African scientists and technicians, community building through holding an annual workshop, and connecting several of the observatories to the internet for near-real time data transmission.

For the duration of this grant, the network of 53 permanent AfricaArray stations was maintained, and data from the seismic, GPS and weather sensors were archived at the IRIS data management center and the UNAVCO data center, respectively.   No new stations were constructed, but some of the stations in South Africa were relocated to more secure sites.  Attempts were made to put stations in Tanzania, Malawi and Botswana online, using the internet for telemetry.   This effort was only partially successful, due to a number of technical factors.  

With the completion of this grant, there is now an archive of broadband seismic data from the network spanning more than 10 years, and GPS and weather data spanning 5 to 8 years.   And over the course of this project, many technicians in Africa have received training on how to install and operate the seismic, GPS and weather sensors, data loggers, and power systems in the stations.  The training has been hands-on, and has occurred in the field during maintenance visits to the stations, and also at the annual AfricaArray workshop, held at the University of the Witwatersrand in Johannesburg, South Africa.  

Data from the network are available at the IRIS data management center and the UNAVCO data center. Data from the AfricaArray network have been used, and continue to be used, by many researchers working on African crust and mantle structure, tectonics, plate motions and climate.    Data from the network has greatly increased the base of knowledge broadly in the Earth Sciences by providing fundamental new observations about the Earth system in Africa.
